summary:
I am a PhD Candidate in Social Anthropology at the University of Cape Town. My research focuses on the reconstitution of kinship and family relations in post-genocide Rwanda. Particularly looking at the social worlds of young people conceived in sexual violence. 

I currently work as Programme Support Consultant with the MHPSS team at UNICEF HQ, in the Child Protection in Humanitarian Action section. As part of this role I am the Co-Chair of the Child and Youth Working Group of the Global Mental Health Action Network (GMHAN). 

I previously worked as HIV Programme Analyst with the United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA) in Harare, Zimbabwe. I have also worked as Sexual Health Research Specialist for SEED Madagascar, a capacity-building NGO based in south east Madagascar. 

My educational background is in Cultural and Social Anthropology with a focus on Applied Anthropology and International Development. 

Interests: Violence, Trauma and Memory, HIV/AIDS, Youth, Sexual and Gender-Based Violence,  Sexual and Reproductive Health, Medical Anthropology, NGOs.

'profile_positions': [{'location': 'Madagascar', 'date': {'start': {'month': 1, 'day': None, 'year': 2013}, 'end': {'month': 9, 'day': None, 'year': 2013}}, 'company': 'SEED Madagascar', 'description': 'I work for Azafady’s Community Health department and am involved in two projects, working closely with the local Malagasy team and other international volunteer specialists. 

Project Safidy is a sexual health peer-education project in the Lycée (high school) of Fort Dauphin, which is currently expanding to the C.E.G (middle school) as well. I carry out the monitoring and evaluation of Project Safidy by conducting written surveys, semi-structured interviews as well as focus group discussions with both students and teachers. I write reports for local stakeholders, Azafady’s internal learning as well as an online monthly blog for the project donor, the Mercury Phoenix Trust. 

Project Mampisaina was Azafady’s HIV/AIDS behaviour change communication (BCC) programme that targeted young people 13-24 years old of Fort Dauphin urban commune, their parents and opinion leaders from 2008-2011. At the moment I am conducting a thorough needs assessment for the development of Project Mampisaina 2, a three-year follow-up project that the Community Health and Project Development teams are now designing. I hold community consultations with different stakeholders ranging from local NGO’s and target group associations to an international mining company and the ministry of health. In a series of meetings, focus group discussions and interviews with potential project partners I single out key-issues that need to be taken up in project design. In addition, I have conducted and analysed a large baseline survey consulting youth across Fort Dauphin on their current sexual knowledge, attitudes and practices (KAP). 

Through my work with Azafady I have developed strong research skills, a critical view on international development in the sexual and reproductive health context, as well as the flexibility to work well within a culturally diverse environment.', 'title': 'Sexual Health Research Specialist', 'employment_type': None}]}, {'company': {'id': 2848659, 'name': 'Azafady', 'logo': 'https://media.licdn.com/dms/image/C510BAQHYlXe_RwJMOA/company-logo_400_400/0/1519896295729?e=1700697600&v=beta&t=X4QRk60fcewYIbcwt8bjvmom0HmSYtC3ByLKPPnD_JQ', 'url': 'https://www.linkedin.com/company/seedmadagascar/', 'employees': {'start': 51, 'end': 200}}, 'date': {'start': {'month': 5, 'day': None, 'year': 2012}, 'end': {'month': 7, 'day': None, 'year': 2012}}, 'profile_positions': [{'location': 'Madagascar', 'date': {'start': {'month': 5, 'day': None, 'year': 2012}, 'end': {'month': 7, 'day': None, 'year': 2012}}, 'company': 'SEED Madagascar', 'description': 'I combined my MSc Social and Cultural Anthropology dissertation research with a research project for ONG Azafady. 

I conducted baseline research in the C.E.G (middle school) in Fort Dauphin in order to advise Azafady on expanding their Project Safidy (sexual health peer-education) to the school, and in what best way this should be done. 

Activities included: 
- A written survey held with a sample of students 
- Focus group discussions with a sample of students 
- Semi-structured interviews with teachers 
- Ethnographic fieldwork among youth in Fort Dauphin 

The research topics were: sexual behaviour and attitudes, relationship dynamics, sexual decision-making and negotiation, gender, socio-economic pressures on youth and knowledge about HIV/AIDS, STIs and pregnancy', 'title': 'Community Health Researcher', 'employment_type': None}]}, {'company': {'id': None, 'name': 'Africa SOMA', 'logo': None, 'url': None, 'employees': {'start': None, 'end': None}}, 'date': {'start': {'month': 7, 'day': None, 'year': 2011}, 'end': {'month': 8, 'day': None, 'year': 2011}}, 'profile_positions': [{'location': 'Elangata Wuas, Kenya', 'date': {'start': {'month': 7, 'day': None, 'year': 2011}, 'end': {'month': 8, 'day': None, 'year': 2011}}, 'company': 'Africa SOMA', 'description': 'Research into livelihood diversification strategies among pastoralist Maasai women.', 'title': 'Intern', 'employment_type': None}]}]
